Seems to me those concerns are more effectively addressed by not serving fries, or making the available snack foods things that are nutritious and require sitting at the table.

In our house, food is always eaten at the table, sitting down. When the kids need snacks, I offer an array of options but they're all pretty healthy. I will limit them based on what else I know they've eaten that day too - for example, I won't offer cheese and crackers if I think they've had too much cheese and starch lately. Then they can choose between carrots, cucumbers and fruit.

You're a scientist and you don't know how to spell the word "false?"  That aside, you might have a point about the price. It seems like a long way before this is affordable. On the other hand, the biotech products are insanely expensive because they can get away with it. People will expect to pay less for food, so this could be viable. Also, many of the true costs are not taken into account in current low meat prices, and that can't last forever.

I totally agree with "reason". As a scientist myself, the expense and waste of this is incredible. And many of the growth factors needed to grow these cells are derived from ANIMALS!!! There are still many growth factors that cannot be made (at great expense) in a lab.
So do we spend the money on expensive lab materials or on pastureland? Is there a better use of pastureland? As someone from a farm state, there is land that works for grazing, but not much else. Growing vegetables is also not a "natural" thing and requires the use of much land.

This is positively insane! Do you realize the amount of waste generated by the production of a what looks like a 1/4 pound of proteins (not to mention the cost). These cells did not grow from water and sun!! They are the result of liters and liters of purified chemicals and reagents, countless disposable sterile plastic containers and instruments and they were grown in temperature and atmosphere controlled containers.
You can get complete proteins from vegetables or fungi or algae TODAY. Japanese are pretty good at modifying texture and add taste. You can be sure that the red of this product is nothing more than added color. And please do not talk to me about how this will become more affordable, etc. because the techniques used to produce this are the same ones used for biotech and biotech products are still insanely expensive despite mass production.
As a scientist, I am appalled at the waste of resources. Feeding the world (and controlling its population) are critical problems but this is a waste of time, gives falls hopes and is distraction from the real urgent problems were are facing on global scale.

I do not see why people are complaining so much.

The cells used were from the shoulder of a cow. Not from unfertilized eggs. No future cows were killed.

If successful, it can turn into a meat making factory, no cows involved. no slaughterhouses, no water polluted. And you can use the same meat, to make more meat. It's self perpetuating.

You would think people would see a benefit from that.

Instead it's a lot of criticism because 'it's icky'.

It can be progress. It can save all those cows people clamor about caring so much about. It can feed mankind. So what's the problem?

I actually had to argue with my dad on this; he was trying to make my son clean his plate. Given that everyone in my family, including my dad, has had weight problems and plainly overeating is habitual for us, I was stunned at how attached he was to teaching another generation the same thing, particularly given that my son is a hearty eater.

I can understand parents treating the issue differently for kids who are very picky eaters or who have had medical concerns with not gaining or growing enough. But a kid who is growing well and who has some veggies and fruits they routinely eat should be encouraged to listen to their own body and stop when they're full.

Yes, but the kid is eight. Sure she should be taught to speak up for herself, but kids are very much still learning that at that age. For some it takes much more time. A caring teacher can certainly make the difference to bridge the gap.

Furthermore, *any* dominant voice among a group of students, male or female, can be intimidating to shyer children who may not thrive if not offered a chance to contribute. Confident children need to learn to listen to their peers too. It's a win for everyone.

Classroom teachers are aware of discussion-leading techniques that specifically allow for many voices to be heard, but depending on the training a camp counselor received, s/he may not be as aware of this issue.
